data.caseTitle: Sharma Family vs. Builder Constructions Pvt Ltd - Breach of Agreement & Specific Performance
data.plaintiffName: Mr. Rajesh Sharma & Mrs. Meera Sharma
data.defendantName: Builder Constructions Pvt Ltd & Director Mr. Anil Kapoor

timeline.description: Booking of Flat No. 402, Tower A, "Dream Homes" project. Booking amount Rs. 5,00,000 paid via cheque
Builder Buyer Agreement signed. Total property value Rs. 75,00,000. Possession promised by March 2023
First installment of Rs. 15,00,000 paid as per payment schedule
Second installment of Rs. 20,00,000 paid despite construction delays
Site visit revealed slow construction progress, only basement complete
Third installment of Rs. 15,00,000 paid under pressure from builder
Builder sent email announcing 6-month delay due to labor issues
Original possession date passed. Project only 40% complete
Multiple buyers filed complaint with RERA (Real Estate Regulatory Authority)
Builder announced additional delay of 12 months without compensation
Legal notice sent demanding possession or full refund with interest
Builder replied refusing refund, offering possession in June 2024
RERA issued show-cause notice to builder for delays
Filed civil suit for specific performance and compensation

claims: Breach of Builder Buyer Agreement by failing to deliver possession within agreed timeline
Violation of RERA Act 2016 for delayed possession without justified reasons
Unfair trade practice by accepting payments despite knowing project delays
Mental harassment and financial loss due to continued rental payments for current residence
Failure to pay promised delay compensation as per Agreement clause 8.2
data.reliefRequested:
1. Specific Performance: Deliver possession of Flat No. 402 within 3 months
2. Delay Compensation: Rs. 10,000 per month from March 2023 to actual possession date
3. Mental Harassment & Agony: Rs. 5,00,000
4. Refund of Additional Rental Costs: Rs. 3,60,000 (Rs. 30,000 x 12 months)
5. Interest on delayed possession at 10% per annum on amount paid
6. Litigation costs and legal fees
7. In alternative, full refund of Rs. 55,00,000 paid with 12% interest per annum
8. Any other relief deemed fit by the Hon'ble Court

evidence.description: Original Builder Buyer Agreement dated 20.03.2021 with possession clause specifying March 2023 delivery
Booking receipt and cheque copy for Rs. 5,00,000 dated 15.03.2021
Bank statements showing three installment payments (Rs. 15L, 20L, 15L) with transaction dates
Email from builder dated 01.08.2022 citing labor shortages and announcing 6-month delay
Photographs of construction site taken during inspection on 20.01.2022 showing minimal progress
Legal notice sent via registered post on 15.07.2023 with acknowledgment receipt
Builder's reply to legal notice dated 01.08.2023 refusing refund
RERA registration certificate of the project showing approved timeline
RERA complaint acknowledgment and show-cause notice to builder
Rental receipts for current residence from April 2023 to March 2024 (Rs. 30,000/month)
Statement from 8 other flat buyers in same project facing identical delays
Email communication trail with builder's customer care (45 emails) requesting status updates

lawSections.description: Return of amount and compensation in case of delayed possession. Mandates builder to pay interest for delay at prescribed rate
Penalty for non-compliance of orders. Empowers authority to penalize builder for violations
Compensation for loss or damage caused by breach of contract. Plaintiff entitled to damages for builder's breach
What agreements are contracts. Agreement is legally binding and enforceable
Suits in which specific performance of contract enforceable. Court can direct builder to perform contractual obligation
Discretion as to extent of specific performance. Court may grant performance with modifications if needed
Definition of deficiency in service. Builder's failure constitutes deficiency in service
Rights and liabilities of buyer. Buyer entitled to receive property as per agreed terms

data.strengths:
1. Strong documentary evidence: Original Agreement with clear possession timeline
2. Consistent payment history: All installments paid on time despite delays
3. RERA backing: Regulatory authority already issued show-cause notice to builder
4. Multiple witnesses: Including independent buyers and ex-employee
5. Clear communication trail: Legal notice sent, proper response received
6. Quantifiable financial loss: Rental receipts, delayed compensation clause in agreement
7. Pattern of misconduct: 8 other buyers facing same issue strengthens case
8. Compliance from plaintiff side: No defaults in payment obligations
data.weaknesses:
1. Builder may claim force majeure (COVID-19, labor shortages) as valid reason for delay
2. Mental harassment compensation of Rs. 5L may be considered excessive by court
3. Rental cost claim may be challenged as consequential damages not directly recoverable
4. Site supervisor witness credibility may be questioned due to ex-employee status
5. Agreement may have generic clauses allowing builder extension in certain circumstances
6. Specific performance may be difficult if builder has genuine financial issues
7. Alternative relief (refund) may be more practical but Agreement may limit refund terms
8. Some evidence (site photos, emails) is circumstantial rather than direct proof of breach

witnesses.name: Mr. Rajesh Sharma (Plaintiff)
witnesses.knowledge: Primary witness. Can depose about agreement terms, payment of installments, site visits, communications with builder, mental stress due to uncertainty, financial burden of continued rental payments

witnesses.name: Mrs. Meera Sharma (Plaintiff)
witnesses.knowledge: Co-applicant and co-owner. Can testify about family's reliance on possession date, planning of daughter's wedding (postponed due to no flat), emotional distress caused

witnesses.name: Mr. Suresh Gupta (Fellow Buyer - Flat 305)
witnesses.knowledge: Independent witness who also booked flat in same project. Can corroborate delays, builder's pattern of false promises, RERA complaint process, site condition during visits

witnesses.name: Advocate Priya Malhotra (Legal Notice Drafter)
witnesses.knowledge: Legal professional who drafted and sent legal notice. Can authenticate notice, confirm service to builder, testify about builder's unreasonable response

witnesses.name: Mr. Vikram Singh (Site Supervisor - Ex-employee)
witnesses.knowledge: Former site supervisor who left company in July 2022. Can provide insider testimony about builder's financial difficulties, material shortages, actual reasons for delays

witnesses.name: Mr. Arun Joshi (Bank Manager)
witnesses.knowledge: Manager at plaintiff's bank. Can authenticate payment transactions, confirm installment payment dates and amounts from bank records
